page.title: 10Local History(1)
page.content: Halifax seems to have been the last place in England to retain the old Anglo-Saxon practice of beheading thieves.Certain lords of the manor had rights and privileges granted by the crown.These enabled the lord to execute certain classes of people found guilty of theft of goods exceeding 5 pence,in value.In most parts of the country this practice died out during the 14th century,but it continued in Halifax until 1650 when the last execution took place.In about 1770,after the Gibbet had been neglected for a number of years,it was used as a rubbish dump.The site was only rediscovered in 1839 when the rubbish was being cleared.In early 1974 the platform was fully reconstructed and a replica of the blade is preserved in Bankfield museum.
